titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to Non-Commercial Disc Collections ARS.0033
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Franz Kunst

publicationstmt.p: The Board of Trustees of Stanford University. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.descrules: Prepared using Describing Archives: a Content Standard

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: The Archive of Recorded Sound's Non-Commercial Disc Collections consist of over 10,000 phonographic disc recordings from a variety of donors, the majority of which are either broadcast transcriptions or instantaneous recordings. None were ever available for sale to the general public, and many are unique.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research; material must be requested at least two business days in advance of intended use. Contact the Archive for assistance.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with repository. Publication and reproduction rights reside with the creators or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Head Librarian of the Archive of Recorded Sound.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Non-Commercial Disc Collections, ARS-0033. Courtesy of the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Archive of Recorded Sound's Non-Commercial Disc Collections consist of over 10,000 disc recordings from a variety of donors, most of which are either broadcast transcriptions or instantaneous recordings. None were ever available for sale to the general public, and many are unique. Despite the variety contained in this collection, the majority are related to radio broadcasting. Recordings were either produced for broadcast or captured from broadcasts as air checks.

Transcriptions were made in a variety of sizes (often 16 inches to accommodate a longer playing time), and were typically vinyl or other plastic pressings, but many were instantaneous. Some earlier transcriptions were made of shellac. These discs reflect the diversity of the Golden Age of radio, with recordings of music, drama, news, commentary, advertisements, public service announcements, and educational programming.

Instantaneous discs, on the other hand, could be made by virtually anyone with access to a recording machine. These were recorded one at a time, and while it was possible to make duplicates, most are also one of a kind. These recordings, sometimes referred to as lacquers, acetates, or soft-cuts, were not the first recordable media (blank cylinders were available since the beginning of recording), but for over twenty years they were the dominant form of recording. The collection even contains a few discs recorded in the mid-1970s.

Content was only bounded by what could be placed in front of a microphone. These discs were used in professional recording studios, concert halls, record-your-own-voice booths, living rooms, and in the field. Some are merely dubs of other recordings; this was especially common with collectors prior to the reissue industry. Others capture live performances and are of inestimable value.

A major component of the collection is armed forces-issued recordings. These were used for a variety of purposes, including recruitment, entertainment, and instruction. Other types of recordings in the collection include soundtracks, sound effects and production discs for motion pictures, promotional giveaways and premiums, and demos and vanity pressings by recording studio clients (not all of whom, it should be noted, were amateurs).

Only a portion of the collection has been described below. Multiple recordings on a single disc, missing and damaged labels, conflicting or no information, and the inability to aurally preview contents make cataloging these discs a challenge. Also, there are serious preservation concerns with ancient recordings on such fragile media. Some discs are no longer playable. The Archive maintains a comprehensive off-line database of the collection. Please contact ARS for further information.

processinfo.head: Sponsor
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced with generous financial support from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission.

odd.head: Complete Inventory
odd.p: A spreadsheet inventory of the entire collection, updated every 6 months as new items are added, is available via the Stanford Digital Repository

did.unittitle: Armed Forces Radio Service / Armed Forces Radio and Television Service / American Forces Radio and Television Service

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Please note that many of these programs were also originally broadcast without AFRS affiliation. Programs here have not been cross-referenced with those without armed forces labels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: includes Music For The Wounded program 7/2/1947.

did.unittitle: Semi-Classical Replacement, San Francisco Symphony Orchestra
Call From Les Paul, A (World Broadcasting System)
Canada Dry a Las Puertas De La Habana

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Almost all feature the singing of Lawrence Tibbett. While these discs were donated by Jerome Kleinsasser, more information about them can be found in the Lawrence Tibbett Collection (ARS0041).

otherfindaid.p: Discs used in the production of recordings by this company. See also the Metal Parts Collections (ARS0126).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Music recordings probably used for local radio broadcast at the Naval Supply Center in Oakland, California

Outpost Concert Series. Music Of The Jazz Bands
Outpost Concert Series. Music Of The Theatre

separatedmaterial.head: Accompanying paper materials
separatedmaterial.p: Cue sheets/scripts, album covers and programs (including bound volumes containing 1932-1955 programs) are available for this series.

separatedmaterial.head: Accompanying paper materials
separatedmaterial.p: Cue sheets/scripts, album covers and programs (including bound volumes containing 1928-1965 programs) are available for this series.

did.unittitle: Symphonies of the Sage (Sons Of The Pioneers)
U.S. Air Force Reserve. Reserved For You
U.S. Air Force Reserve. Soundflights Into Jazz
U.S. Department Of The Interior Fish And Wildlife Service, Bureau Of Commercial Fisheries
U.S. Office of Civilian Defense. Yankee Doodle
Celebration Of The First Anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Commemoration Of The Second Anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights
UNESCO. Energy In The Service Of Man
UNICEF. Meanest Man In Town, The
UNICEF. Trial of Sergeant Bill, The

Voice Of America. Musica De Siempre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For the most part, content types have been identified for genres other than music. Quantities are estimated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label information suggests relatively informal speech, singing and playing by family or friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio and pressing plant information has been recorded when present. Please note that the general ARS record library also contains many custom and privately-printed recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes soundtracks, production discs (largely from MGM 1940s musicals), promotional recordings and advertisements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News, commentary, panel discussion, speeches, lectures, sportscasting, etc. Most are from or for the radio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some identified as dubs may not be issued takes, and there are probably other dubs not identified as such. Many appear to be party records (i.e. risque songs not otherwise easily available in record stores).

did.unittitle: African Music Research discs from Johannesburg, South Africa
Aboriginal Music From the Northern Territory of Australia (Australian Broadcasting Commission, Processed By Columbia Graphophone)
Cook Island Songs Recorded For The South Seas Commission (Columbia Graphophone (Aust.) Pty. Ltd.)
Finnie Collection recordings from Lebanon, Venezula, Korea and elsewhere for use in Bechtel films
Folk Songs and Dances From The Pacific, Recorded by Fred Drilhon (Australian Broadcasting Commission, processed By Columbia Graphophone)
Linnell Migratory Camp, Visalia, California. A. Carl Killion - Turkish Lady B. Evelyn Pennington - Old Grumbler

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This unusual 16" cardboard-based lacquer was recorded by Nadean Hart in 1945. This recording has been deposited at the Library Of Congress American Folklife Center as part of AFS 9434-9447: Nadean Hart Collection of Folk Songs and Ballads. It is unclear what relationship this disc has to the AFS collection. It is probably a contemporary dub.

did.unittitle: New Guinea and Papuan Native Music (Australian Broadcasting Commission, processed By Columbia Graphophone)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two glass-based discs recorded by Albuquerque Radio and Appliance featuring Mike Reyna, Paul Toya and Heinrich Shultz singing traditonal Taos Pueblo songs as well as popular material (such as "Bomb the Berlin"). These discs were originally owned by Virgil Whitaker, a Stanford alumnus and professor emeritus who worked in the Indian Education Service in New Mexico during WWII. However, the original recordings were made by anthropologists Florence Hawley Ellis and Donovan Senter, and these are probably copies made at the time. For more information refer to the Florence Hawley Ellis and Donovan Senter Collection of Hispanic, Isleta, and Laguna Songs at the University of New Mexico Center for Southwest Research.

did.unittitle: Sam Kapa, J. Louis Hila, Donald Parshon, Cazimero. Kaikoo ; Lihiwai [photocopy of lyrics in Hawaiian enclosed]
Sanscrit Chant, Sri-Sulul (Aladdin Recording, Portland, Oregon)
Sarat Lahiri and Todi, Sitar, Tabla and Banya, 341 West 58th St. New York City - Raga Behag ; Hindu Love Song [handwritten label]
Sydney University Expedition 1949. Chants And Rituals Recorded By Professor Elkin (Australian Record Company)
San Francisco Symphony Orchestra and Opera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Not all Stanford-related discs have been identified, and some recordings donated by faculty and alumni have no relation to Stanford. The collection contains donations from Sandor Salgo, Herbert Nanney, Leonard Ratner, Harold Schmidt, Jan Popper and many others. Many transcriptions were once part of KZSU's library. While most discs are of various baccalaureates, commencements, and other addresses, a few highlights are as follows:

David Starr Jordan's "The Stanford Spirit" on a 1916 custom shellac pressing ; an interview with Mrs. David Starr Jordan in 1951 ; Richard Lyman home recordings from the early 1930s ; Stanford Women's Glee Club 1937 ; Stanford Symphony Orchestra conducted by Sandor Salgo and Leonard Ratner ; original recordings of the Stanford Scalp Song from composer Irving Bibo ; Stanford Players productions from the late 1940s ; Ray Lyman Wilbur and D.B. Tressider at an Alumni Banquet in 1943 ; Yvor Winters readings ; Wallace Stegner singing the song "Sam Hall" ; Herbert Nanney playing the organ at Memorial ; a Putnam Aldrich harpsichord recital from 1953 ; Stanford Big Game Gaieties from 1940.

relatedmaterial.p: Other Stanford-related collections at the Archive of Recorded Sound include the Stanford Recital Collection (ARS0021), Stanford Tape Collection (ARS0112),Stanford Speech Collection (ARS0022),Meyer Library Lecture Tapes (ARS0116),Preservation Master Tape Collection (ARS0097),Stanford Program for Recordings in Sound Collection (ARS0104),Roy A. Long Collection (ARS0086),KZSU collection (ARS0062),Stanford Marching Band Collection (ARS0089), and the Harold Schmidt Collection (ARS0120).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By no means is this an exhaustive list. Many of the donors below also have their own collections, and links are provided to their finding aids.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Bob Arnold Collection (ARS0080).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arnold was a collector and researcher in Berkeley, California. Some or all discs are from Jaxyson Radio Service in Oakland, a studio which was known for a few blues and gospel pressings, as well as many instantaneous recordings (many of which were compiled on a commercial CD set titled The Jaxyson Records Story).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six discs compiling rare recordings by singer Joseph Bentonelli.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Al Block Broadcast Collection (ARS0077).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Block was a collector and long-time friend of the Archive. Most of these discs were from the last of his many donations. While his interest was mainly in classical, one may also find dramatic performances, popular music and even a country and western program (the Sons Of The Pioneers' Symphonies of the Sage).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also Box 34, Tape 26 in the Richard Bonelli Collection (ARS0005).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Richard Bonelli with Fern Sayre, soprano, G. Alexander Schriener, organ, Mormon Tabernacle Choir. Brahms, Johannes, 1833-1897. Deutsches Requiem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discs originally owned by cellist and composer Alexander Borisoff and donated by his grandaughter Janice Ortega. Includes a complete Your Hit Parade (Lucky Strike) program on NBC/KFI from 9/14/1935 and a 1949 private recording of Borisoff's Poeme Ancient by the Hollywood Symphony Orchestra conducted by Victor Young with Borisoff playing cello and narration by Edward G. Robinson.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Nate Brown Western Sound Archive Collection (ARS0124) and the Ed Wilkinson Collection (ARS0092).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Western Sound Archive, run by collector and trader Nate Brown along with fellow collector Ed Wilkinson, was a non-profit service that distributed rare classical recordings on open reel tape. These discs were the original sources for much of this privately circulated material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Exact provenance is unclear; discs may have been donated by an intermediary. Davis was a jazz fan and recording engineer originally from Wichita, Kansas who worked as an electrical engineer and for the Seeburg jukebox company. An associate of John Steiner, they ran the S.D. (Steiner-Davis) and Paramount reissue labels together, and recorded traditional jazz performances both live and from radio broadcasts in the Chicago area. Most of these discs have minimal annotations, and some may be dubs or tests of commercial issues. Notable recordings include: Sunday Swing Concert, Sherman Hotel in Chicago 11/3/1940 ; Teddy Wilson, Duffy's Tavern 4/7/1942 ; Bob Crosby, Jess Stacy, Fitch Bandwagon 5/24/42 ; George Barnes, Roy Shields Program WMAQ 5/21/42 ; Bill Davison - Blatz Palm Gardens 5/30/41 ; and various recordings of Mel Henke, Don Ewell, Billy Maxted, Floyd Bean, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drob was a jazz record collector and researcher devoted to trumpeter Bunk Johnson. Many of these discs are dubs from rare jazz 78s, but others may be unique recordings. The Boris Blinder records are probably not part of this donation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A few discs from the collection of famed San Francisco music critic and radio producer Phil Elwood. Most discs are unidentified, but there are two of Bill Russell Introducing and playing with Bunk Johnson and an undated Kid Ory aircheck.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the discs in the Ted Fagan Collection (ARS0008).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Richard Finnie Collection (ARS0117).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discs from Richard Sterling Finnie, donated by his widow. Finnie was a writer and producer who worked for Bechtel and traveled around the world making recordings for use in promotional films. He was also an enthusiastic home-recorder, with many hours of radio broadcasts in his collection. Most of the discs here are 1940s airchecks of popular music from WEAF, WABC, WNEW, and other stations, but there are also original field recordings of ethnic music from Lebanon, Venezula, Korea, and Trinidad, and folk music by Massachusetts pipline worker P.G. Spike Downes (mosty of which are also exist as tape transfers in the Finnie Collection).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Arnold Jacobsen Collection (ARS0122).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arnold Jacobsen was a record collector and dealer with a specialization in popular music of the early-to-mid 20th century. The discs here reflect that broadness, and include many airchecks and transcriptions. There are also discs of Jacobsen's radio program The Memory Shop (named for his record store), audio letters he made while in the army, and several location recordings of temple services.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kapfenberg's donation largely consists of pressed transcriptions, but there are also several location recordings of San Francisco Bay Area dance bands, such as John Wolohan Orchestra at the El Patio Ballroom in 1946-47 and the Jack Fina Orchestra at the Claremont Hotel in 1946. Most discs are in very poor condition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hal Layer is Professor Emeritus at San Francisco State University and a man of diverse interests (http://userwww.sfsu.edu/~hl/). His collection here includes CBS Symphony, NBC Symphony, and New York Philharmonic airchecks, WBBM broadcasts, Nat King Cole's Wildroot Cream Oil program, and many pressed transcriptions.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Jack Lund Collection (ARS0045)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most discs are a performance of Otello by the NBC Symphony Orchestra under Toscanini 12/6-13/1947.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malloch was music director at KPFK, artistic director of the Ojai Music Festival, and a music teacher at UCLA. All discs from his collection are instantaneous-cut, and contain rare recordings of the NBC Symphony, New York Philharmonic, Cleveland Symphony, San Francisco Symphony, and other orchestral performances.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also William R. Moran Sound Recording Collection (ARS0075).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Moran was a collector, researcher, writer, and discographer, particularly in the field of early sound recordings and vocal art music. Moran was one of the founders of the Archive of Recorded Sound, and he donated thousands of rare recordings and ephemera to the Archive until he passed away in 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One of the largest single donations of transcriptions and instantaneous discs to the Archive. Among the many offerings: Standard Hour and Standard School Broadcasts ; AFRS discs stamped U.S.S. Antietam and Oneida ; Royal Hawaiian Minstrels on Stichting Radio Omroep [Netherlands] in 1949 ; several San Francisco Sketchbook programs on ABC 1951-1952 ; many Masterworks From France programs ; a KGO program on Socialism.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Howard Rhines Collection (ARS0102).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Howard Rhines was a composer, announcer and program director at Los Angeles classical radio station KFAC.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: This collection contains only 16" discs from Schmidt. Smaller-sized discs remain in the Harold Schmidt Collection (ARS0120).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Schmidt was choral director and a professor of music at Stanford. These discs are primarily two sets of the Stanford Players' performance of Britten's Peter Grimes, May 27-29, 1948.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the James Schwabacher Collection (ARS0024).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cynthia is the sister of singer and voice teacher James Schwabacher, and although the James Schwabacher Collection also contains lacquers, it would seem that their collections have been mixed to a certain degree. Nevertheless, the discs included here are probably all from Cynthia, and offer a remarkable snapshot of 1940s radio, including news, sports, comedy, and political programming.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Waggener was a saxophonist who ran a professional recording studio in Southern California, but spent much of his free time perfecting his home recording system. Almost all of these discs are air checks, most from stations KFI, KFAC, KFWB, and KCBH. Some of are from television programs. Waggener meticulously logged his recording setup on disc sleeves, but usually only wrote a few notes about what was being recorded. Many appear to be broadcasts of transcriptions or pre-recorded music, but there are undoubtedly many undiscovered and unique recordings in a donation of this magnitude.
